question.body: Predict the ratio of combination that would occur should sodium and sulfur be added to a solution.

multiple_choice.choice: Sodium would form the anion Na+; sulfur would form the cation S2-; NaS2
Sodium would form the anion Na-; sulfur would form the cation S2+; Na2S
Sodium would form the cation Na+; sulfur would form the anion S2-; Na2S
Sodium would form the cation Na+; sulfur would form the anion S2-; NaS2

response.feedback: That is not quite right. Positive charges are referred to as cations; negative charges are referred to as anion.

That is not quite right. Sodium's orbital arrangement is 2.8.1, easier to loose 1e- than gain 7e-, forming a cation; sulfur's orbital arrangement is 2.8.6, easier to gain 2e- than loose 6e-, forming an anion.

Good Job. Sodium, low electronegativity, 2.8.1 orbital arrangement will loose 1e- forming the cation Na+; Sulfur, high electronegativity, 2.8.6 orbital arrangement will tend to gain 2e-. Ratio of combination Na+: S2- will be 2:1 therefore Na2S.
If sodium forms the cation Na+ and sulfur the anion S2-, you would need 2Na+ for every S2- not vice versa.

part.hint: Sodium has 11 electrons whereas sulfur has 16 electrons
Arrange electrons in respective orbitals, not exceeding the maximum orbital capacity.
Sodium is a metal, low electronegativity, tends to loose ; sulfur is a non metal; high electronegativity, tends to gain.
Balance out the positive and negative charges on each respective ion to cancel each other.
Correct answer is C. Sodium loses 1e- to form Na+; sulfur gains 2e- to form S2-; ration 2:1 Na2O
